milestone_48_hint_213_v2: Use positive words and give attention to behaviors you want to see (“wanted behaviors”). For example, say “You’re sharing that toy so nicely!” Give less attention to those you don't want to see.

Give {{himHerTag}} a choice of what {{heSheTag}} can do instead. For example, "You can't jump on the bed. Do you want to go outside and play or put on some music and dance?"
milestone_48_hint_215_v2: Let your child play with other children, such as at a park or library. Ask about local play groups and pre-school programs. Playing with others helps your child learn the value of sharing and friendship.
milestone_48_hint_216_v2: Eat meals with your child when possible. Let {{himHerTag}} see you enjoying healthy foods, such as fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, and drinking milk or water.
milestone_48_hint_217_v2: Create a calm, quiet bedtime routine. Avoid any screen time (TV, phone, tablet, etc.) for 1 to 2 hours before bed and don't put any screens in your child’s bedroom. Children this age need 10 to 13 hours of sleep a day (including naps). Consistent sleep times make it easier!
milestone_48_hint_218_v2: Take time to answer your child’s “why” questions. If you don’t know the answer, say “I don’t know,” or help your child find the answer in a book, on the Internet, or from another adult.
milestone_48_hint_219_v2: Teach your child to play outdoor games with friends, such as tag, follow the leader, and hide and seek.
milestone_48_hint_220_v2: Spend time speaking to your child in complete sentences, using "grown-up" words. This will help {{himHerTag}} learn better speaking skills and helps with future reading and writing skills.
milestone_48_hint_221_v2: Let your child help with simple chores, such as bringing in the mail, feeding a pet, or wiping down tables. This helps build independence.
milestone_48_hint_222_v2: Teach your child to stop and wait when excited by playing red light, green light, or freeze dance (play music, turn it off, and have everyone freeze when it stops).
milestone_48_hint_223_v2: Play your child’s favorite songs and dance with your child. Take turns copying each other’s moves.
milestone_48_hint_224_v2: Give your child time to solve {{hisHerTag}} own problems with friends. For example, if they are arguing over who gets to be which superhero, let them work it out. Stay nearby to help if needed. If they can’t work it out, use questions to help them think of other solutions.
milestone_48_hint_225_v2: Use words, such as “first,” “second,” and “finally.” When playing, telling stories, or doing chores, ask your child what comes next. This will help your child learn about the order of events.
milestone_48_hint_226_v2: Comfort your child if {{heSheTag}} is afraid and talk about {{hisHerTag}} fears. For example, "Monsters can feel scary even though they are not real and can’t hurt you." Help your child learn things {{heSheTag}} can do when {{heSheTag}} is afraid, such as hugging a stuffed animal.
milestone_48_hint_227_v2: Play simple games, such as Tic-Tac-Toe or matching games.
milestone_48_hint_228_v2: Try to make time for active play each day. Your child will have more fun if {{heSheTag}} can choose the activity. For example, give {{himHerTag}} choices, such as playing music and dancing together, playing outside, or taking a walk together.
milestone_48_hint_229_v2: Help your child notice when {{heSheTag}} hurts someone's feelings by describing what you see. Encourage {{himHerTag}} to say sorry and help {{himHerTag}} find a way to make the person feel better.
milestone_48_hint_230_v2: Take trips to the library to let your child pick out books.
milestone_48_hint_231_v2: Limit screen time (TV, tablets, phones, etc.) to no more than 1 hour per day of a children’s program with an adult present. Don’t put any screens in your child’s bedroom. Children learn by talking, playing, and interacting with others.
milestone_60_hint_232_v2: Let your child play with other children, such as at a park or library. Ask about local play groups and pre-school programs. Playing with others helps your child learn the value of sharing and friendship.
milestone_60_hint_233_v2: Your child might start to “talk back” in order to feel independent and test what happens. Limit the attention you give to the negative words. Find alternative activities for {{himHerTag}} to do that allow {{himHerTag}} to take the lead and be independent. Make a point of noticing good behavior. “You stayed calm when I told you it’s bedtime.”
milestone_60_hint_234_v2: Teach your children about safe touch, such as hugging when both people want to and touches that help keep children healthy (touches from doctors or parents). Unsafe touches are touches that might make a child feel hurt, uncomfortable, scared, or confused. Teach your children that they are in charge of who touches them. Help them practice saying ‘no’ to unwanted or unsafe touch and let them know there are adults they can turn to for help.
milestone_60_hint_235_v2: Teach your child to look for “helpers” if {{heSheTag}} is lost or needs help, such as parents with children, a store clerk with a badge, or a police officer. Teach your child {{hisHerTag}} name and your name (first and last names).
milestone_60_hint_236_v2: Use words to help your child begin to understand time. For example, sing songs about the days of the week and let {{himHerTag}} know what day it is. Use words about time, such as today, tomorrow, and yesterday.
milestone_60_hint_237_v2: Play with toys that encourage your child to put things together, such as puzzles and building blocks.
milestone_60_hint_238_v2: Let your child do things for {{himHerTag}} self, even if he doesn’t do it perfectly. For example, let {{himHerTag}} make {{hisHerTag}} bed, button {{hisHerTag}} shirt, or pour water into a cup. Celebrate when {{heSheTag}} does it and try not to "fix" anything you don't have to.
milestone_60_hint_239_v2: Teach your child to follow rules in games. For example, play simple board games, card games, or Simon Says.
milestone_60_hint_240_v2: Talk about and label your child's and your own feelings. Read books and talk about the feelings characters have and why they have them.
milestone_60_hint_241_v2: Play rhyming games. For example, say "What rhymes with cat?"
milestone_60_hint_242_v2: Ask your child what {{heSheTag}} is playing. Help {{himHerTag}} expand {{hisHerTag}} answers by asking “Why?” and “How?” For example, say "That’s a nice bridge you’re building. Why did you put it there?"
milestone_60_hint_243_v2: Set limits for screen time (TV, tablets, phones, etc.) for your child, to no more than 1 hour per day. Make a media use plan for your family.
milestone_60_hint_244_v2: Create a calm, quiet bedtime routine. Avoid any screen time (TV, tablets, phones, etc.) for 1 to 2 hours before bed and don't put any screens in your child’s bedroom. Children this age need 10 to 13 hours of sleep a day (including naps). Consistent sleep times make it easier!
milestone_60_hint_245_v2: Eat meals with your child and enjoy family time talking together. Give the same meal to everyone. Avoid screen time (TV, tablets, phones, etc.) during mealtime. Let your child help prepare the healthy foods and enjoy them together.
milestone_60_hint_246_v2: Create a spot in your home for your child to go to when {{heSheTag}}'s upset. Stay nearby so your child knows {{heSheTag}} is safe and can come to you for help calming as needed.
milestone_60_hint_247_v2: Encourage your child to “read” by looking at the pictures and telling the story.
milestone_60_hint_248_v2: Encourage your child to pretend play. Help your child find items {{heSheTag}} can use to play dress up, school, or house.
milestone_60_hint_249_v2: Keep a box of crayons, paper, paint, child scissors, and glue for creative play. Encourage your child to draw and make art projects with different supplies.
milestone_60_hint_250_v2: Take your child to the playground. Teach {{himHerTag}} how to pump {{hisHerTag}} legs back and forth on a swing and help {{himHerTag}} play on the monkey bars.
milestone_60_hint_251_v2: Play games that help with memory and attention. For example, play card games, Tic Tac Toe, I Spy, or Hot and Cold.
milestone_60_hint_252_v2: Read to your child. Ask questions, such as "What is happening in the picture?" and "What do you think will happen next?"
milestone_60_hint_253_v2: Explore things your child likes. For example, if {{heSheTag}} loves animals, get some library books about animals, look for birds and squirrels in a park, or visit a zoo to learn about animals.
milestone_60_hint_254_v2: Try to make time for active play each day. Your child will have more fun if {{heSheTag}} can choose the activity. For example, give {{himHerTag}} choices, such as playing music and dancing together, playing outside, or taking a walk together.
milestone_60_hint_255_v2: Your child might start to talk back or use profanity (swear words) as a way to feel independent. Do not give a lot of attention to this talk, other than a brief time out. Instead, praise your child when {{heSheTag}} asks for things nicely and calmly takes “no” for an answer.
milestone_60_hint_256_v2: Help your child be ready for new places and meeting new people. For example, you can read stories or role play (pretend play) to help {{himHerTag}} get ready for Kindergarten.
